description: From Middle English destitute, destitut, from Latin dēstitūtus.

adjectives.description: destitute (comparative more destitute, superlative most destitute)

entries.meaning: (followed by the preposition "of") Lacking something; devoid
examples: Now, though this region may scarcely be said to be wedded to science, being to all intents a virgin territory as respects the enquirer into natural history, still it is greatly destitute of the treasures of the vegetable kingdom.

In 1907 he moved from St. Louis to New York City, arriving as a famous composer. But he died a decade later at the age of 49, destitute in an asylum on Wards Island as ragtime was fading in popularity.

description: From Middle English destituten, from the adjective (see above).

verbs.description: destitute (third-person singular simple present destitutes, present participle destituting, simple past and past participle destituted)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To impoverish; to strip of wealth, resources, etc.
